summary.p: This manuscript of the Bālambhaṭṭī, a commentary on the Mitākṣarā, was part of the library of Philippe-Édouard Foucaux. According to a title page in his hand, it was copied from a manuscript in Fort William, Calcutta, in 1866. It contains numerous annotations in his hand, in both French and Sanskrit.
The Mitākṣarā itself is a commentary on the Yājñavalkyasmṛti, an ancient law text.

As noted on the title page, the commentary is traditionally ascribed to Bālambhaṭṭa. However, the colophon attributes authorship of the text to his mother, Lakṣmīdevī, and names the text Lakṣma (or Lakṣmī, in the edition of Nityānand Pant Parvatīya). Accordingly, scholars such as Julius Jolly have referred to the text as the Lakṣmīvyākhyāna.

Lakṣmīdevī seemed to have been well-known; Fitzedward Hall refers to her as the famous Lakshmí Deví (1859, 175). Based on biographical information about her son Bālaśarman (or Bālakṛṣṇa, as named in the colophon), Jolly places Lakṣmīdevī in the 18th century, and the composition of the text around 1750 with a terminus ad quem of 1782, based on a Benares manuscript (1896, 32; 1892, 270; 1885, 15).

additions.desc:
Title page, in Foucaux's hand: Glose par Bâlam Bhatta du Commentaire de la 2e Partie du Livre des lois de Yâjñavalkya. _ Msc. copié à Calcutta sur un Msc. du Fort William
1866.
The old shelfmark, D. 276, and the entry in the registry of acquisitions, R. C. 6137, are given on the title page.

After the title page, Foucaux has translated a passage by Colebrooke, describing the text: « La glose de Bâlambhaṭṭa est sous la forme ordinaire d'un Commentaire perpétuel. Elle procède sentence par sentence expliquant chaque phrase et chaque terme du texte original. Elle suit, en général, la Soubôdhinî (autre glose plus ancienne) aussi loin que va celle-ci, et y ajoute souvent des explications quand cette glose ne dit rien, ou quand ses expressions trop consises, ne sont pas assez intelligibles. » The reference for this passage is given below the quote: (Colebrooke, Two treatises on the hindu law of inheritance, Preface, p. IX.)
Library stamp on folio 1 recto and folio 433 verso: BIBLIOTHÈQUE IMPÉRIALE MSS.
Binding instructions on folio 1 recto: coller une feuille mince de même couleur.
Marginal notes throughout the manuscript, in Foucaux's hand, in red and grey pencil.

origin.origDate: According to the title page, the manuscript was copied from another manuscript in Fort William, Calcutta, in 1866.

provenance.p: Part of the library of Philippe-Édouard Foucaux.

acquisition.p: Philippe-Édouard Foucaux sold the manuscript to the BnF in 1869, for 200 francs.
